content.text: The coefficient of \(x^{7}\) in the expansion of \(\left(p x^{2}+\frac{4}{p} x\right)^{5}\) is 1280.
Find the value of the constant \(p\).
Find the rate at which the \(y\)-coordinate of \(P\) is changing when \(x=9\). Give your answer in terms of the constant \(a\).
5 The equation of a curve is \(y=4 \cos 2 x+3\) for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 2 \pi\).
State the greatest and least possible values of \(y\).
Sketch the curve.
Given that the curve has a minimum point when \(x=\frac{1}{4}\), find the value of \(a\).
[Turn over
Hence determine the number of solutions of the equation \(4 \cos 2 x+3=2 x-1\) for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 2 \pi\). [1]
The diagram shows the curve with equation \(y = \frac{9}{(5x + 4)^{\frac{1}{2}}}\) and the line \(y = 6 - 3x\). The line and the curve intersect at the point \(P\) which has \(y\)-coordinate 3.
Find the area of the shaded region.
A point \(P\) is moving along the curve with equation \(y=a x^{\frac{3}{2}}-12 x\) in such a way that the \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) is increasing at a constant rate of 5 units per second.
Prove the identity \(\frac{\tan \theta+7}{\tan ^{2} \theta-3}=\frac{\sin \theta \cos \theta+7 \cos ^{2} \theta}{1-4 \cos ^{2} \theta}\).
<label>
Hence solve the equation \(\frac{\sin \theta \cos \theta + 7 \cos^2 \theta}{1 - 4 \cos^2 \theta} = \frac{5}{\tan \theta}\) for \(0^\circ \leqslant \theta \leqslant 180^\circ\).
Find the coordinates of \(A, B\) and \(C\).
Find the angle \(A C B\) in radians. Give your answer correct to 3 significant figures.
The chord \(A B\) divides the circle into two segments.
Find the area of the larger segment.
© UCLES 2025
[Turn over]
The diagram shows the circle with equation \(x^{2}+y^{2}-14 x+8 y+36=0\) and the line \(y=-2\). The line intersects the circle at the points \(A\) and \(B\). The centre of the circle is \(C\).
Find an expression for \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}\).
UCLES 2025
Find the \(x\)-coordinate of the other stationary point of the curve, and determine the nature of this stationary point. [2]
Find the equation of the curve.

Find the equation of the normal to the curve at the point where \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}=-\frac{9}{4}\) and \(x\) is positive. Express your answer in the form \(p x+q y+r=0\), where \(p, q\) and \(r\) are integers.
The equation of a curve is such that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} y}{\mathrm{~d} x^{2}}=-\frac{24}{x^{3}}\). It is given that the curve has a stationary point at \((-2,19)\).
Find the value of \(k\).
Find the sum of the first 20 terms of the progression.
The first, second and third terms of an arithmetic progression are \(4 k, k^{2}\) and \(8 k\) respectively, where \(k\) is a non-zero constant.
The fourth and sixth terms of a geometric progression are 36 and 6 respectively. The common ratio of the progression is positive.
Find the sum to infinity of the progression. Give your answer in the form \(\frac{a}{\sqrt{b}-c}\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers.
Express \(x^{2}+4 x+2\) in the form \((x+a)^{2}+b\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers.
Find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\).
